Let $a_1,a_2,\ldots$ be a sequence of integers with $a_n\to \infty$. Is\[\sum_{n} \frac{\tau(n)}{a_1\cdots a_n}\]irrational, where $\tau(n)$ is the number of divisors of $n$?



Erd\H{o}s and Straus \cite{ErSt71} proved this is true if $a_n$ is monotone, i.e. $a_{n-1}\leq a_n$ for all $n$. Erd\H{o}s \cite{Er48} proved that $\sum_n \frac{d(n)}{t^n}$ is irrational for any integer $t\geq 2$.

Erd\H{o}s and Straus further conjectured that if $a_{n-1}\leq a_n$ for all $n$ then\[\sum_{n} \frac{\phi(n)}{a_1\cdots a_n}\]and\[\sum_{n} \frac{\sigma(n)}{a_1\cdots a_n}\]are both irrational.

This problem has been formalised in Lean as part of the Google DeepMind Formal Conjectures project.




References


[Er48] Erd\H{o}s, P., On arithmetical properties of Lambert series. J. Indian Math. Soc. (N.S.) (1948), 63-66.

[ErSt71] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Straus, E. G., Some number theoretic results. Pacific J. Math. (1971), 635-646.
